newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft expanding Internet games effort.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft expanding Internet games effort.

text.p: Microsoft Corp., a laggard in the computer games industry until recently, plans to launch a new version of its Internet Gaming Zone Monday that executives hope will attract thousands of new players.
Microsoft has invested heavily in games over the past two years, particularly with the launch of the Windows 95 operating system, its first successful platform for game developers since DOS.

As part of a companywide drive to capitalise on the Internet, the software giant has ramped up its games investment, buying several game companies including Electric Gravity Inc., designer of the Internet Gaming Zone.
The free site, at http://www.zone.com/, has grown to 200,000 registered users from 15,000 just last May, said Steve Murch, product unit manager.
On Monday, Microsoft will take the wraps off several enhancements to the zone including "lobbies" where players can find partners for 11 games including bridge, chess and Microsoft Golf, Murch said.
The games also will include online versions of Monopoly, Scrabble, Risk and others to be offered under a partnership with Hasbro Interactive Worldwide, a unit of Hasbro Inc.

The game matching service will be free, but Microsoft expects to make money from advertising, increased sales of game software and subscription fees for upcoming "massively multiplayer games," such as a golf tournament and a fighter pilot game that each can handle thousands of online players, Murch said in an interview.
"We really think that new entertainment experiences and the games that emphasise social play are critical to the success and the growth of the category," Murch said.

The company hopes to continue increasing its share of the $1.2 billion market for computer game software, where it has risen to No. 3 or 4 from as low as No. 10, and to help expand the overall category, which still is overshadowed by the much-larger video game industry.
"We're really interested in the category growing first and foremost because it's very good for Windows 95 and for the Internet," Murch said.
